titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p:
1. IV:30. Tuesday. It has been established as a usage since Mr Monroe came to the Department of State, that the Heads of Department return the first visit, and no others of the foreign Ministers— This usage differs from that of Great-Britain, and the European Nations where the Ministers of States return no visits of foreign Ministers, except Ambassadors— I returned this morning the visit of the new Russian Envoy Poletica— I called first at O’Neal’s hotel, where he had lodged, but found him at his house, to which he removed last Friday. It is that which was occupied by Mr Bagot— He soon afterwards sent Lomonossof to me at the Office with Copies of Protocols at Aix la Chapelle; chiefly relating to the Slave trade; and an opinion concerning the treatment of Napoleon Bonaparte at St. Helena, written as Poletica says by Pozzo di Borgo, and presented to the Congress. It has been published in the Newspapers that the Emperor of Russia had made a proposal at the Congress that the harsh treatment and imprisonment of Napoleon should be mitigated— It is exactly the contrary— This memoir insists that he should be treated with more rigour, harassed with more mortifications; and forced to submit to more daily and hourly insults— Napoleon said lately “ils me tuent à coups d’epingles”— The Russian memoir thinks there are not pins enough employed, and throws in a paper morè. I have some question why Poletica communicated this paper to me— Whether it is merely to sound the opinion of this Government, or to take away the opinion that the Emperor Alexander has any feelings of generosity or of Compassion for Napoleon— The memoir
considers Napoleon as an outlaw, the common prisoner of all the allied powers, and whom they consider as having forfeited all the rights both of a sovereign and an individual— It pretends to a common Jurisdiction of the allies, not only over him, but over all the members of his family, and insists that they should be compelled to reside at the places assigned to them— As Joseph resides in this Country, perhaps they intend to make the attempt of dictating to him some other place of abode— Napoleon has concentrated upon his individual person more of the hatred of mankind than any other individual of the age— He has perhaps done more evil than any man living— He attained greater power than any one has exercised since the days of Charlemagne, and his abuse of power was in proportion to its extent— His fall was, as punishment to him, the consummation of Justice. No agony of sufferance can be too exquisite, no prolongation of torture too excruciating for the depth and magnitude of his offences against his species—but he is punished by instruments in a moral point of view no better than himself—base and ignoble instruments, who with all his depravity, have none of his redeeming greatness— Mr Frye called at the Office— He returned Sunday morning from Richmond, where he was summoned as a witness to the execution of a Bond to the United States, by the sureties of a certain officer now deceased— To get rid of the bond, they pretend it was executed in Blank; and afterwards filled up— Frye, who filled it up, testified that it was not; but the two defendants and two witnesses of kin, and perhaps co-interested with them, swore that it was— The jury could not agree and were discharged—nine for the United States and three for the defendants— Frye was deeply affected, at having his character for veracity thus unexpectedly brought into controversy, without the slightest foundation, and there must have been great profligacy on the other side— I wrote little at the Office, and left my Letters to G. W. Campbell and Pedersen, unfinished— Walk round the Capitol Hill, after dinner— Mrs Adams spent the Evening at her sister Frye’s, and came home quite ill; having heard of the death of Mrs Hellen.

2. IV:30. After the Journal of yesterday, I resumed the arrangement and preparation of the Convention Journals for the Press. It is truly “in tenui labor”— The longer I brood upon it, the more protracted and unprofitable the toil becomes— The Journals and papers were very loosely and imperfectly kept. They were no better than the daily minutes from which the regular Journal ought to have been, but never was made out— I find on close inspection a great number of questions, some of them important, entered on the loose-sheets of yeas and nays, and not entered at all in the Journal. I intend to have them all inserted at their respective places on the Journal— There was one loose page of yeas and nays, of which I had been able to make nothing until this Morning, when I found it must have been the Secretary’s first expedient for taking down the yeas and nays. The page is divided into thirteen columns, with the initials of the names of the States, from New-Hampshire to Georgia, numbered from 1. to 13. at the head of the page; but no space is left on the page, either to enter the question upon which the yeas and nays were taken, or the sum of the votes on either side— There are five successive sets of the yeas and nays taken, not summed up; and with nothing to indicate upon what question they were taken— After these, the New-Hampshire column is divided into two, upon which the sum of the yeas and nays on each question is entered, to the bottom of the page; and in eight instances, at intervals, the question upon which the question was taken is crowded into the square of the Rhode-Island column— New-Hampshire and Rhode-Island, were the two States, not then represented, and their columns of course remained in blank, after the yeas and nays were taken, and entered— There are twenty-eight questions the result of which appears upon this page; on the other side of which is the name of Mr Gorham with seven strokes of the pen, and that of Mr Rutledge with one by their side— This is obviously the noting down of the vote by ballot for a Chairman to the Committee of the whole. The vote for Rutledge was probably Gorham’s— He was at that time President of the old Congress— Before Jackson the Secretary had got half down this page he found the want of spaces to enter the questions upon which the votes were taken, and the sums of the yeas nays & divided votes.
The sheets that he afterwards used were divided accordingly; but he entered upon them only a part of the questions that he had already taken down on the first experimental page— He began with the question of a “Single Executive”—which is the seventeenth on the experimental page— He entered it the first, on his book of yeas and nays, and then resorted again to loose sheets; after filling two of which he returned to his Book, leaving blank pages, apparently to have the contents of the loose sheets copied upon them. The single executive question, being the first entered on the book, was the first with which I found the corresponding question in the Journal of the Committee of the whole; and from that time I traced the questions in the Journals, and collated them with the questions on the sheets of yeas and nays— This left however a number of questions on the Journal of the Committee of the whole, taken before that of the single Executive, but not noted either on the book, or on the loose sheets of yeas and nays, and the yeas and nays upon which I had hitherto been unable to trace— This morning I first noticed the coincidence of the “Single Executive” question, the first entered upon the Book, and the seventeenth upon the experimental page; and immediately inferred that the sixteen preceeding votes entered on the page, must have been upon the Questions taken in the Committee of the whole, before that upon the single executive— But to which question each set of the yeas and nays applied was yet to be traced out; the ninth and fifteenth of the questions, being the only two, entered upon the Rhode-Island square— I traced the questions on the Journal to the first taken in the Committee of the whole, apparently by yeas and nays, and was collating it with the first vote on the experimental page of yeas and nays, when the consumption of time in this petty research brought it to past noon, and I was obliged to break if off, and go to my Office— Commodore Perry called at my house, and took leave; going to Baltimore; and thence, to Annapolis to sail in the John Adams, upon his cruize and mission to South-America— At the Office I had a visit from Mr Saltus of New-York— Received despatches to 12. April from R. Rush, and a Letter from B. Irvine late Agent at Venezuela, and who has arrived at Philadelphia, and Baltimore— Finished my draughts of Letters to G. W. Campbell and P. Pedersen— Mrs Decatur and the Commodore passed the Evening here—

3. V:Ward Marston a son of Mr John Marston of Quincy, and now a Lieutenant in the Marine Corps, brought me this morning a Letter of introduction from my brother— At the Office I despatched my Letter to G. W. Campbell, and began one to M. Furstenwaerther— Rode home with Mrs Adams— She passed the Evening out, and W. S. Smith was here— Mr Bailey was also here, with Mr Baptis Irvine; just returned from Venezuela— He brings no news; and has been too much of an enthusiast in the South-American cause to get much information upon which dependence can be placed. The same thing has happened to almost every agent employed by this Government, in South-America. They supply the place of truth and judgment, with zeal.

4. IV: A man by the name of Jenkins, a writing master, who said he originally came from Dorchester, but belonged now to New-York came this morning with a printed sheet of texts of Scripture, prayers, verses and pious admonitions against duelling, which he had the project of having reprinted— He had also a printed certificate signed by all the Clergymen of this place, and some others recommending this device as exceedingly useful. He came to obtain my approbation and signature to the same certificate— I declined signing it, and told him I made it a general rule not to give certificates of recommendation, for any thing which if useful must carry its recommendation with itself. He then entered into a long argument to convince me that it was the duty of men whom Providence had placed in high situations, to patronize and recommend poor and ingenious persons, who for want of countenance in the world, were often robbed of their most useful inventions, as to his knowledge a Mr Smith had been, and was consequently starving with a large family of children, and as indeed he himself had been, of his system of handwriting— I gave him, I thought very temperately my reasons for declining generally to give certificates of recommendation, and he went away— My wife who was present thought I had treated him harshly and no doubt he thought so still more himself— I thought the man’s anti-duelling printed sheet of bible texts and prayers, a devise worse than useless—liable to the derision of Scoffers, and utterly inadequate ever to prevent a single duel— To have recommended it, would with my opinions have been to countenance an
imposition upon the public— I felt it an impertinence in a man a total stranger to me, to come and ask my certificate of recommendation to such mummery, and still more to open upon me a lecture of half an hour upon the duty of a man in high office to patronize and recommend poor and ingenious persons like him. I bore all this with composure—answered his allegations upon the duty of Patronage; and said nothing passionate, or personally offensive to him: but my wife says that I looked all the ill temper that I suppressed in words— The result is that I am a man of reserved, cold austere and forbidding manners; my political adversaries say a gloomy misanthropist, and my personal enemies, an unsocial savage— With a knowledge of the actual defect in my character, I have not the pliability to reform it— At the Office came Mr Baptis Irvine, and gave me some further particulars from Venezuela— He is a fanatic to the South-American cause, and sees every thing through the medium of his prejudices— Such a person is always a bad observer— He, and Worthington and Rodney and Brackenridge, all stand looking in extatic gaze at South-America; foretelling liberty, to South-America, as the Jews foretell the Messiah— Graham and Poinsett have not only seen more clearly, but in secret Reports, which they are afraid of having published, have told the Government much of the naked truth— Bland alone, though he went out perhaps as great an enthusiast as any of the rest, saw the whole truth, and did not shrink from telling it out. His report contained more solid information, and more deep and comprehensive reflection than all the rest, put together; but he is now attacked for it— Irvine was desirous of going to Annapolis to see and converse with Commodore Perry, to whom I gave him accordingly a Letter— As from various symptoms I perceive that the late Treaty with Spain, will probably not be ratified at Madrid, and as the refusal will produce a reacting explosion here, I this day selected all the papers of the negotiation relating to the subject, and directed copies of them to be made to have them ready for the meeting of Congress. Mr Poletica, and Mr Lomonossoff called here, after dinner, but we were going out and did not receive them— With Mrs Adams, I attended a tea and Evening party at Mr Weightman’s. Had some Conversation with Mr Hyde de Neuville, who says the Spanish Government will not and cannot delay the Ratification of the Treaty on account of the grants. That he has proofs not only that Onis intended and understood that the three great Grants were null and void; but that the Spanish Government knew that such was the intention and understanding. But these proofs he said he could only communicate to his own Government— He admitted however that Onis had been disingenuous, and had spoken indiscreetly upon these points, after the questions arose; but he thought it was only for the sake of giving his Court the opportunity of making a merit of waving any objection to the ratification.— The weather is at full summer heat.

5. VI: I made an attempt to write a second Letter to the Secretary of the Navy, for a supplementary Instruction to Commodore Perry; but the interruptions of visitors prevented me from finishing it, and I am afraid that on Monday it will be too late, as he will probably sail to morrow, or Monday. Dr Sewall of the District of Maine, brought me a Letter of introduction from his kinsman, the late U.S. District Judge David Sewall. The Doctor is travelling Southward, partly for health, and partly with views of Settlement somewhere— He took away with him Judge Sewall’s Letter, which he was desirous of using as an introduction to Mr Sewell on the Capitol Hill whose acquaintance the Doctor wished to make as a namesake, and perhaps, though he did not know, a kinsman— Mr Poletica came, and enquired if I had no objection to tell him the object of the expedition going out as announced in the Newspapers under the orders of Commodore Perry— I told him in Confidence that the object was to carry into Execution the Acts of Congress, relating to Piracy and to the suppression of the Slave-trade; to communicate the former to the Governments of Venezuela, and of Buenos-Ayres, and at the same time to make Representations to those same Governments against the privateering piracies carried on in their names, and under their Commissions— He said this would be rendering a real service to some of the commercial Nations of Europe— He asked me, if I had read the Protocols that he had sent me— I had only read part of them. He asked if I had noticed Lord
Castlereagh’s Memoir, proposing the adoption of the principle of a right of mutual search for the suppression of the Slave trade— I had— He said it was a remarkable proposal and had been resisted by the Russian Ministers. I said I hoped they would persevere in their resistance; for the British Government had made the same proposal to us, and were very urgent in pressing us to its adoption. And I had observed that notwithstanding the answer of Russia to the Memoir to which he had alluded, and notwithstanding the still more decisive opposition of France at Aix La Chapelle, Lord Castlereagh after having been subsequently to the termination of the Congress at Paris had written to his Government, that there was reason to expect that both France and Russia would ultimately yield the right of mutual search. He said he did not know upon what grounds Lord Castlereagh could have entertained this expectation. He knew that both Nesselrode, and Capo d’Istria, but most especially the latter were determined against acceding to any such principle; and he knew that Count Lieven had received a reprimand in a nexript, or despatch signed by the Emperor himself, for having received a Memoir of the same kind, and only answered that he would forward it to his Court without undertaking to refute it— He said that Russia, had no disposition to indulge Great-Britain in her encroachments upon maritime Law— That even at Vienna England had made a jealous alliance with Austria, against Russia; whom she considered as the preponderating power in Europe, and as having taken the place of France— At Aix la Chapelle they had even drawn Prussia into their system, and every day as long as the Congress lasted, the Russian Ministers on arriving at the Conferences invariably found England, Austria and Prussia arrayed in opposition against them. France had indeed handsomely supported Russia in opposing this principle of mutual search; but Austria and Prussia would have acceded to it— As to the British allegation that this right of search would be reciprocal, it would be a mere sport upon words, while Russia had neither slave traders, nor armed vessels employed to capture them. I told him that when the President returned I should ask leave to communicate to him the substance of what had passed between us and the British Cabinet relating to the suppression of the Slave trade. Mr Mitchell the late Consul at Martinique, brought me a Gazette of St: Pierre’s, received from Silas Marean the present Consul, containing the Ordinance, which prohibits foreigners from being settled as Merchants in the island— I was engaged about two hours in taking 25 pages of Press copy, made out by the Clerks on the affair of the Florida Land-grants—which I am preparing for communication to Congress— With Mrs Adams, I attended this Evening a tea-party at Mr Wirt’s. Mrs Wirt and her daughter Laura, performed well on the Piano. Thermometer this day at 84— We paid a visit to Mrs Monroe, before going to Wirt’s.

6. VI: Fahrenheit at 88. a day of blazing heat— I was confined to the house till after dinner and was in a great degree disqualified for writing by the weather. I nevertheless took up again the Convention Journals, and finally completed the examination of the experimental page of yeas and nays. a hard, and thankless and useless toil. After dinner we rode to the Navy yard, and thence to Mr Hyde de Neuville’s, where Mrs Adams and Mary Hellen passed the remnant of the Evening— I walked home. Quarrel of Conrad & Philip. The hot Nights are commencing— At Bed time, Fahrenheit was at 82.

7. IV:15. Potowmack Bath, between six and seven O’Clock this morning. It was just at the time of high water, and I took Antoine with me. At the Office, Mr Van Ness brought several Letters of recommendation to the President, in favour of a Citizen of Vermont, to be a judge in the expected future territory of Florida. The bear’s skin has been pretty effectually distributed before he is caught. Mr Cathcart came also to the Office; lately returned from a survey I believe, for the Commissioners of the Navy, of the Alabama territory, and in the State of Louisiana. The accounts of those Countries hitherto published he represents as being very incorrect— After dinner, Mrs T. Peter with two of her daughters, came to pay a visit, but Mrs Adams, was just going out, by an appointment with Mr and Madame Hyde de Neuville— I went with them, and we spent the Evening at Mr Samuel Harrison Smith’s; who resides about three Miles out of the City— It was eleven in the Evening when we got home— Fahrenheit at 89. Power of writing prostrated by the heat.

8. V: Potowmack Bath alone at seven O’Clock this morning. High Water; and the Moon full, last Night about eleven O’Clock. At the Office, Mr Baptis Irvine called, having returned from Annapolis where he saw Commodore Perry. He gave me further particulars of the state of Affairs in Venezuela, the Independence of which he thinks will be finally established during the present year. I finished the second draught of an Instruction Supplementary for Commodore Perry, in a Letter to the Secretary of the Navy. The Conversation with Irvine, and the perusal of Bolivar’s speech at the opening of the Congress of Venezuela, suggest the expediency of a third Instruction, for which I shall not have time— I am afraid even this second one will be too late to reach him before he sails— Mr Hyde de Neuville sent me not long since a project for a Consular Convention; with remarks of his own, which I at length finished reading this day— As it can come to nothing the time spent upon it will be as bad as wasted; yet I must give de Neuville some answer— The excessive heat of the weather is a considerable interruption to business, and application of any kind is painfully laborious. I rode to my Office, but walked home— We spent the Evening, with a numerous tea party at Mr Parrott’s at Georgetown— Came home between eleven and twelve at Night— Thermometer 88. at Noon and 80. with a flat calm at Midnight. Dismissed our Coachman Conrad.

9. V:30. Fahrenheit at 90. Sixth successive day of overpowering heat; with a blazing Sun, which even at seven O’Clock this morning was so fierce that I omitted going to the Bath— Rode to and from my Office. Mr B. Irvine was there, and left with me the account for his Salary to be settled. I made some enquiries of him, as to the proceedings in Venezuela, but could obtain little satisfactory information. His animosities against Bolivar have much subsided; but his experience has been in conflict with his preconceived enthusiasm, in favour of the South-American cause, which was also a party doctrine to him. His agency has nevertheless contributed to furnish some information of the real state of that Country. Mr Greenwood a Clergyman of Boston, brought me a Letter of Recommendation from my father. Young Bulfinch came with him. He is going to Richmond and Monticello— Mr Lomonossof came to enquire if I could forward a second despatch for Mr Poletica. I received a despatch from J. Forsyth, dated at Cadix 18. April— He arrived there on the 14th. after a passage of eighteen days from Boston— There was also a despatch from G. W. Erving; but of an old date, and a duplicate. Nothing of the Treaty. I was occupied great part of the day in taking Press Copies of Papers for Commodore Perry. After dinner, I went with Mrs Adams and Mary Hellen to Mr Law’s Country House in Prince George’s County, about two Miles beyond the Bridge over the Eastern Branch. Mr Law had given us many invitations there, and within the last fortnight we had been twice disappointed of going. We therefore went this Evening though under the immediate threat of a heavy thunder storm; which actually overtook us, and in the midst of which we arrived at the house, just at dark. He had given over all expectation of seeing us, and was gone to bed— He was however immediately roused and came down, and gave us a treat of Coffee, Strawberries and Cherries. The thunder showers were severe, and lasted so long, that about eleven we left his house in the midst of one, which was not entirely over when we reached home at Midnight. The Moon, just past the full, prevented entire darkness— We saw of course nothing of Mr Law’s farm.

10. VI: The weather has moderated, and Fahrenheit’s thermometer was about 75 all this day, which was generally cloudy; but it did not effectually restore an aptitude to labour; but I was overpowered the greater part of the day, with a lethargic drowsiness, which continued the disqualification. Yet I was much of the morning grubbing into the yeas and nays of the federal Convention of 1787. At the Office, I found Mr Crawford, the Secretary of the Treasury, had been there, with a Letter from M’Culloh the Collector of Baltimore to him, and a list of the Cargo, of a vessel now sitting out there, to be sent to St. Thomas, and sold for a Slave trader, or privateer— She was originally a prize to one of the South-American privateers— Sold to a Baltimore Merchant who is now fitting her out for this laudable purpose— One hundred sets of manacles and fetters form a part of the Cargo. M’Culloh under these Circumstances refused to clear out the vessel, until he could receive the orders of the Secretary
of the Treasury, to whom he wrote this statement of the facts; and Crawford as he has done in many other cases involving an invidious responsibility, referred the papers to me, though the Department of State had no more to do with them than the Land-Office. A Mr Murray, sent by the owner of the vessel to hurry an immediate answer, came and Crawford referred him to me— I went over to Crawford’s Office, returned him the papers, and gave him my opinion upon them; which was that the equipment of the vessel was without doubt in violation of the Law of 1818. Upon which Crawford asked me to write to the District Attorney, and direct him to commence a Prosecution. This I declined, because the Law contemplates no such interference by the Department of State, and I see no reason for volunteering it. Crawford is enormously sensitive to this two edged responsibility, which brings invective, whichever side the decision is made— I find no fault with him for that; and when the responsibility falls properly to my own Department, I never shrink from it. But Crawford’s attempts to shift off his proper share of it upon me are not so well; and he has repeated them till they are as transparent as crystal. I advised him to write to the Collector, that as the Law did not make it his official duty to seize and prosecute vessels in this situation, he must act upon his own responsibility, and prosecute or clear the vessel as he should think proper— Crawford also told me much of the information which he is receiving with respect to the operations of the Banks, and the gigantic frauds practising upon the People by means of those Institutions— The Banks are breaking all over the Country; some in a sneaking, and some in an impudent manner, some with sophisticating evasions, and others with the front of highwaymen. Our greatest real evil, is the question between debtor and creditor, into which the banks have plunged us deeper than would have been possible without them— The Bank debtors, are every where so numerous and powerful, that they controul the Newspapers, throughout the Union, and give the discussion a turn extremely erroneous, and prostrate every principle of true political economy. Crawford has labours and perils enough before him in the management of the finances for the three succeeding years— My time was so absorbed with this interview, that I had none left to write at my Office; if I had been otherwise adequate to it. After dinner we had Evening visits from W. S. Smith and his wife; Mr and Madame Hyde de Neuville, and Dr Sewall; who returns immediately to Massachusetts without going as he had intended to Richmond and Monticello, but who proposes to come back here, and settle, to practice in his profession.

11. IV:45.My wife has made a translation of the first and second Alcibiades of Plato, from that of Dacier in the Bibliotheque des Philosophes. She made it for the benefit of her sons, and I this morning finished the revisal of it; in which I have made very little alteration— I read the first Alcibiades at Auteuil, in the year 1784 at the age of seventeen. The folly of that presumption, which would rush to the management of public affairs, without a stock of knowledge concerning them; the meanness of setting up as the standard of our own acquirements, those of our associates—the indissoluble union of moral beauty and goodness, the indispensable duty of seeking self knowledge and self-improvement; and the exalted doctrine which considers the body as merely the mortal instrument of the Soul; and the Soul alone as man, made a deep and lasting impression upon my mind— The beauties of the composition did not then so much affect me— The dramatic character of the dialogue, though remarked by Dacier— The transitions from grave to gay; the playful, but cutting Irony, mingled with the deep Pathos of the appeals of Socrates to the sense of shame in his vain, and thoughtless, yet ambitious disciple, struck me less than the pure and glorious moral sentiments inculcated in his discourse— The lessons of Socrates were lost upon Alcibiades; they were not entirely so upon me. Neither from them; nor from the moral principles that I gathered from other sources, have I derived all the benefit that I might have done. My conduct in life has been occasionally warped by the passions of my nature; by the frailty of my Constitution; by the weakness of my head and of my heart— But it has always been my will, and generally my endeavour to discharge all my duties in life, to God, to my fellow creatures and to my own Soul. I wish my Sons to read, and to be penetrated as deeply as I have been with the lessons of the first Alcibiades. George is now at the same
age, at which I read it, and I hope that this present from his Mother will be useful to him— At the Office I had visits from General John Mason, Mr Andrew Way, and Mr Frye. General Mason came to commend judge Bland, for the appointment of Judge of the United States District Court in Maryland, in the room of Mr Houston who is just dead. Mr Way to make some arrangements concerning the house in F. Street which I have agreed to purchase of him. I told him that if he could dispose of it otherwise, I should be glad to be released from the bargain. Mr Frye came to ask advice concerning the renewal of the Bond of a paymaster of a Regiment in the army, named Larned; one of whose Sureties wishes to be released from his obligation—another Surety is to be substituted. I advised the taking of an entire new Bond. I wrote only a very short Letter to Antrobus the British Chargé d’Affaires. Mrs Adams spent the Evening at her Sister Frye’s— I walked round the Capitol Hill; and could not finish reading the daily Newspapers.

12. V:15. Morning visit from Mr T. Law. At the Office, came Captain O’Brien, formerly Consul and before that a captive nine or ten years at Algiers. He said he had some unsettled business at the Department, upon which he would call again some day next week. Mr Poletica likewise called, with a despatch for Count Nesselrode, which he requested me to forward, for him— He did not wish to have it go by the way of England, because he knew they always broke open Russian despatches, and particularly his, when they could get at them— Mr Daniel Brent was absent from the office, and my own time there was wasted— Rode home in the midst of a Thunder shower— Mrs Adams was unwell great part of the day, and did not dine with us; but we passed the Evening at Mr Hyde de Neuville’s, with a small party— He spoke to me of a man named Renovalés; now living at New Orleans; who first went there as a partizan of the Mexican Insurgents; but afterwards sold himself to the Spanish Government, upon which affair it was, that Onis sent Noëli to New-Orleans. This Renovalés de Neuville says wrote some time ago to him; recommending that France should reassert her right to Louisiana; and now he has written and sent to Spain a long memoir, urging that the late Treaty should on no consideration be ratified; as the object of the Americans is to overrun the Province of Texas and Mexico— He was a mischievous intriguer, but it was to be hoped his memoir would arrive after the ratification of the Treaty, or that it would have no influence. De Neuville was also very inquisitive this Evening, about the return of the President; whether he had been sent for as was pretended in the Newspapers, and whether it was likely there would be an extra Session of Congress this Summer. I told him there was no foundation for the stories that have been circulated; that the President had not been sent for, and there was no prospect of an extra Session of Congress— And so according to present appearances it is— But how the collection of the revenue will stand through the Summer, is problematical; and if as there are strong grounds for expecting there should even be a delay to the ratification of the Spanish Treaty, there may be a call of Congress to meet before the regular period in December— I played one game of Chess with Lomonosoff.

13. VI:15. I took up again the examination of the yeas and nays, to the Journal of the federal Convention of 1787 and collated one full sheet of them with the questions on the Journal. This tedious and trivial drudgery is now drawing to a close— The day was fine and moderate, and I walked before dinner to the Potowmack bridge. And after dinner a short ride with Mrs Adams and Mary Hellen. We stopped and passed the Evening at Commodore Decatur’s, where we found Mr and Mrs Cutts— Mrs Lowndes and Miss Rutledge, Mrs Middleton, and her two daughters, and the Viscount de Quabeck afterwards came in— Conversation languid.

14. IV:45. A Mrfrom the State of Ohio came to the Office, for a certified extract from the Journals of the old Congress, shewing that Samuel Osgood, Arthur Lee, and Walter Livingston were in the year 1785 appointed Commissioners of the Treasury. There are no copies of their Commissions in any of the public Offices, and the Evidence of their having held those Offices is wanted to authenticate some title to lands in Ohio, the sales of which were made by them. Mr Lomonosoff also came twice to enclose the despatch from Mr Poletica to Count Nesselrode, under cover to Mr Pozzo di Borgo, the Emperor of Russia’s Ambassador at Paris. Mr David Hoffmann of Baltimore
came with a recommendation, signed by almost all the members of the Bar there, of E. Glenn the District Attorney, to be the District Judge in the place of Mr Houston, just deceased. He had also a Letter from Judge Duval to Glenn, shewing much earnestness in his favour— Hoffman gave me also many particulars of information respecting the Baltimore privateers with South-American Commissions, which for the last three years have committed enormous depredations upon the Commerce of Spain, Portugal, and other maritime Nations. He promised to send me a great mass of Depositions, relating to this subject, upon which I think it will be necessary for the Government to take a distinct and marked course hereafter, but in which there must be great prudence, moderation and impartiality as well as firmness. Hoffman was with me till past six O’Clock— Mrs Adams spent the Evening at her sister Frye’s— I walked round the Capitol Hill.

15. V:Mr Penniman of Baltimore came, concerning his vessel, which he proposes to sell in the West-Indies, and which is intended for the Slave trade. Mr Crawford answered M’Culloh the collector’s Letter last week according to the opinion of the case in which we concurred: but the Collector replies, and Glenn the District Attorney now proposes that all the parts of the Cargo suitable for the Slave-trade or for privateering should be landed and deposited in the public warehouses, and that a clearance may then be given— Mr Jones the chief Clerk in the War Department sent Penniman to me, for a decision; Mr Crawford being absent— There is a defect in all the Laws against the Slave-trade, inasmuch as it is not made the duty of any public officer to prosecute for infraction of them, nor is there any authority given to the Collector to refuse a clearance even to a vessel notoriously equipped for it— I desired Mr Brent, to answer Jones that the vessel might have a clearance, on the conditions mentioned in Mr Glenns Letter. Captain O’Brien some time Consul at Algiers, came with old claims of more than twenty years standing, and an enormous bundle of vouchers in support of them, which he desired me to inspect and examine— O’Brien is a very original and eccentric character. I promised him to examine his papers as soon as it should be in my power. Mr Hyde de Neuville called to enquire if I had any Letters from France, by a vessel just arrived from Havre— I had none— He urged again, his project for a Consular Convention; but I told him I doubted whether the President would be willing to conclude a Consular Convention, without a general Treaty of Commerce. He had mentioned to me that there was a French Squadron now in the West-Indies, and that they had orders to take from any South American privateer with which they meet any Frenchman whom they should find on board— I remonstrated in the strongest terms with de Neuville against this order, as contrary to the Laws of Nations; as utterly useless for the suppression of piracy, and as giving pernicious countenance to the British practice and doctrine of impressment. After some discussion he agreed with me on the principle and promised to write to his Government concerning it. I desired him also to urge them to enter so far into relations with the South-American Governments as to exercise an influence to prevent them from sanctioning the piracies committed under their Commissions and flags. I promised to send him the Buenos-Ayres privateering ordinance, and told him the substance of the Instructions given to Commodore Perry. He appeared well disposed to second this movement, and we must mature this subject further— I am yet somewhat unwell, and this Evening took a ride in the Carriage, with Mrs Adams and Mary Hellen.

16. IV:30. Three hours wasted this morning in assorting newspapers— Took up again the Journals of the Convention with which it seems as if I never should finish— At the Office I wrote short Letters to C. Hughes at Stockholm, and to C. Pinkney the Secretary of Legation at St. Petersburg— Evening party at Commodore Decatur’s. Mr Hay, who has returned from Richmond was there. Poletica asked to see me to-morrow at the Office— There were about one hundred persons of the company— Evening warm. Chess with Lomonosoff.

17. VI: Still engaged upon the Convention Journal, the end of which recedes, as I seem to approach it. Mr Poletica called at the Office at one O’Clock— He began by inquiring if the squadron under the command of Commodore Perry had been reinforced— It had not— An article which has appeared in some of the newspapers erroneously stating that the Ontario was to join this squadron gave occasion to the question, which with every other
circumstance in the conduct of Poletica, shews the close attention given to every incident in which we are employing an armed force. But Poletica’s special object this day was to tell me that the Emperor was earnestly desirous that the United States should accede to the Holy Alliance— He said he mentioned it now, unofficially and confidentially, that it might be so communicated to the President— That if on Consideration of the subject, it should be concluded that on account of popular prejudices against this compact, it would probably not be agreed to here, I might in a friendly manner let him know it, and he would avoid making any official proposal of it. I told him I could say nothing positive upon the subject, until after the President’s return; but he knew the reason upon which Great Britain had declined, acceding to that Alliance— It was an autograph Treaty, concluded by threeSovereigns, in person; and not by their Ministers— But in Great-Britain the king could make no national compact in person— There must be a responsible Minister to sanction every thing. The English Prince Regent therefore, could not sign the Treaty; but declared his entire approbation of its principles. The executive power in our Country was still much more restricted in our Country, than in England— No Treaty could be concluded, but with the concurrence of two thirds of the members of the Senate, before whom it must be laid— He said he should be perfectly willing that it should be submitted to the consideration of the Senate— That the British Government had indeed answered, as I had stated; but the Swiss Republic had acceded to the Alliance, and he would send me a copy of their act of adhesion— The Treaty was nothing, in specific engagement; it was every thing in respect to general influence— It was a league of Peace, and had hitherto preserved a universal Peace in Europe. The Emperor wished the United States to become Parties to it; because in that case if we had any little points of difference with European Powers, with Great-Britain for instance, He could interpose his influence in their favour. I said it would at all Events be advisable to ascertain what were the dispositions of the members of the Senate, before it would be proper to lay the Treaty before them; in which he concurred. I received this day a very voluminous mail; and among the rest some Letters of no pleasant character— The affair of ten Cate’s Bills is at last however settled, and the money has been paid— It has been altogether a transaction, in which there was on my part a slight indiscretion; which consisted in advancing him the money, without having the sanction of the President for it. He was at the time in Virginia; and I consulted Calhoun, who advised making the advance. But if the Dutch Government had been tenacious upon ten Cate’s want of authority, it would have proved a troublesome, and vexatious affair— A much more troublesome one might indeed have arisen from a refusal to make the advance, for ten Cate, could not have gone without the money; and might have been arrested, and bred a quarrel about his diplomatic privilege— On the whole the transaction has resulted well; but it is one of those of which I cannot acquit myself of error, from imprudence, in acting without the sanction of the President— In the Evening I walked round the Capitol Hill— Mr Bailey was here with Mr Greenwood of Boston, just returning from Mr Jefferson’s house at Monticello— Mrs Adams spent the Evening at her Sister Frye’s, and Mary Hellen at a party.

18. IV:30. Bathed in Potowmack river, taking Antoine with me. I forgot to mention that yesterday morning, Dr Thornton brought to my house a Letter from Mr Thomas Cooper of Philadelphia, telling him that he hears Thornton is going upon a Mission to South-America, and recommending to him an Englishman named Griffin, to go with him as collector of natural history— He also shewed me his answer, in which he tells Cooper that it is not certain that he will be honoured with a mission to South-America; that it cannot be decided till after the President’s return; and so forth. He said he thought it best not to send this answer, till after having communicated it to me. At the Office, William Parry came with complaints of having been employed in the ordinance department, and placed under the command of boys— This is a self-conceited restless uneasy Englishman, who all the time I was in England was teizing me with his intention of coming to this Country; which I discouraged as much as I could— He came however at a venture last Summer, and has been employed but is
discontented, and now comes with Letters and documents to shew me what great sacrifices he made in England, and what great offers he declined to go to South-America, in coming here— He had a plan with him of some floating magazine, for the Commissioners of the Navy— I was this day without interruption at the Office, and draughted a Letter to Mr Madison; again upon the Convention Journals— Fahrenheit was at 91 with a sky perfectly clear, a blazing Sun, and almost total calm— It was gasping weather; and after the Sun was down the heat scarcely abated— Mrs Adams had received an invitation from Mrs Middleton to take an Evening walk at Kalorama, but from the heat of the weather did not go. She spent the Evening at her Sister Smith’s— I was compelled to retire to bed as soon as it grew dark; incapable even of meditation.

19. V:15. The heat of the Night was too great for repose; I slept very little— Fahrenheit about 84 the whole Night. I bathed alone in the Potowmack, and the prospect was of a day more oppressive than yesterday— But just before Noon the wind from the South west came round to the Northwest, and brought a thunder-gust with a very light sprinkling of rain— The remainder of the day was beclouded, and comparatively cool— Lomonosoff came to the Office, with the despatch for Count Nesselrode, which is to be forwarded by an opportunity direct from Boston to St. Petersburg. I examined the parts of the secret Journals of the old Congress which have been copied for publication, and finding in the Volumes several important documents, particularly those relating to our former Consular Convention with France, and to that which had been previously signed by Dr Franklin and the Count de Vergennes, I became so much engaged in the perusal, that it occupied all the office hours of the day. Forbes and Mr and Mrs W. S. Smith called here after dinner, but we spent the Evening at Mr Hyde de Neuville’s, where I lost two games of Chess with Lomonossof.

20. IV:15. Bathed in the river. Mrs Adams was very unwell; confined to her bed until near dinner time. I closed at last the examination of the Convention Journals, but still left something to be done; for which I wrote a Letter to Mr Madison. MessrsPoletica and Lomonossof called after dinner to take leave. They are going on visits to Mr Jefferson and Mr Madison and to Richmond— Mr and Mrs W. S. Smith were also here.

21. V:30. Morning bath— My wife left the City to make a visit to her sister, Mrs. Boyd at Mount Pleasant, Port Conway, 20 Miles from Fredericsburg, Virginia. She took her maid Bridget with her. I accompanied her to the Steam-boat Washington, at the wharf, by the Potowmack Bridge— The Steam-boat left the wharf just before one O’Clock— Mr Poletica and Mr Lomonossoff were on board. At the Office, Mr Cathcart called and gave me an account of his late survey in Louisiana, and in Alabama; indicating upon Darby’s map of Louisiana the places where they found live Oak— But he says that both Darby’s map and his description of the Country are extremely incorrect— A Mr Ferdinand Ernst came with a Letter of recommendation from Mr Wichelhausen the Consul from Bremen at Baltimore. Ernst is a German who has come to this Country with projects of Settlement for himself and some others; but without having determined or absolutely knowing where to go. I had much conversation with him, and after cautioning him against the arts of the Land-jobbers here and at Baltimore, I promised him a Letter for a friend in the State of Illinois, and wrote one for him to D. P. Cook, at Kaskaskia. He was to have called for it again at the Office; but did not come. He called this Evening at my house, and as he wished to return to morrow Morning to Baltimore, I promised to forward to him there the Letter, for Mr Cook, which I had left at the Office— Mr Crawford returned this Evening to the City.

22. III:45. Waiting for the answer to the Letter which I wrote on Saturday last to Mr Madison, I took up this morning an Account of agency sent me last February by Edward Cruft, who has the management of my real Estate in Boston, since it was declined last year by my brother. I found the account and vouchers all correct, and then took up my brother’s Account for the year 1818. some particulars of which I found requiring further explanation from him. From that I resumed an examination of his agency accounts from 5. August 1800, to 8. September 1817. when we came to a Settlement; which was made upon an imperfect examination and review of his Accounts, and therefore not entirely satisfactory either to him or me. As I am now to make entries on my own books, collected from his Accounts, it is necessary to make them as accurate as possible.
I therefore began the review of them, and was absorbed in it all the morning to the neglect even of this Journal— At Seven O’Clock, I went and bathed in the Potowmack— It was the day of the New-Moon, and the tide was up at that hour— At the Office; I took up with Mr Brent the secret Journals of the old Congress, which are being copied for publication, and compared the manuscript copy with the Volume. We revise also the copy of the volume in process of publication by Gales and Seaton. I called upon Mr King the Painter, who is to take my Portrait for Mr Delaplaine; and agreed to sit to him at eleven O’clock to-morrow. Mr Frye was at my house this Evening. He says Coll. R. M. Johnson of Kentucky has failed.

23. IV:30. Still engaged in the re-examination of my brother’s Accounts. Bathed at eight O’Clock this Morning— Sat to King the Painter from eleven to one O’Clock, when Mr Hyde de Neuville who is also sitting to him, came in— Called at the Metropolis Bank, and took up my note for 5000 dollars, giving a new one for 4000. Mr Mitchell the late Consul at Martinique, brought to the Office a new established printed Tariff, for that Island. There was a heavy thunder-gust this Evening.

24. IV:45. Bathed at eight O’Clock, the tide having already turned. It was not very high, the Spring tide having been that of the last Evening. I shall now suspend my bathing for a week until the approach of the full moon— Sat the second time to Mr King the Painter— A short sitting, after which I attended at Mr Crawford’s Office a Meeting of the Commissioners of the Sinking Fund. The object of his calling the meeting was to pass a Resolution authorising the purchase of public Stocks generally, the Resolution at the last Meeting having limited the authority to the purchase of three per Cents— It was therefore now resolved to extend the authority with a recommendation to purchase in preference Louisiana Stock, upon which a payment of nearly three Millions of dollars is to be made on the 21st. of October next, and as that payment may be called for in specie, every portion of the Stock purchased for the Public reduces the amount which will be payable to individuals.— The pressure of embarrassment among the people arising from the depreciation in the value of our exports, from the excess of our importations, from the extravagant multiplication of Banks, and the unprincipled manner in which many of them have been managed; from the foolish, facilities which they have furnished, of contracting debts, and the necessity now compelling them to demand repayment, is increasing from day to day. The failures of Banks in every part of the Country are numerous— Those of individual merchants in our principal Sea-Ports are still more so— County Meetings have been held in the Western States and in some of the Atlantic States—and Petitions for special Calls of their Legislatures, and of Congress are in circulation: the object of which is to obtain suspensions of Specie payments by Law; and execrable device, of which the British Parliament have made the example infectious. Hitherto the counter-spirit is so strong that the expedients of desperation have not succeeded— The majority of the popular meetings have declared themselves against special calls of the Legislatures— The petition for the Call of Congress has not met much Countenance; several of the great failures, which have happened, were so notoriously occasioned by gambling speculations, and have brought to light such Scenes of dishonourable conduct, that they have had a tendency to make complaint itself disreputable. But the disease is only disclosing its first symptoms. New-England scarcely yet feels it— They produce none of the great articles of export, which have sunk within a few Months in the foreign Markets to half price. Cotton, Tobacco, Rice, Wheat and Flour—on the contrary as they import all these Articles for their own Consumption, the fall in their prices, operates thus far to their advantage. They have been far less licentious, in their banking practices, the Banks in Boston never having suspended Specie payments, not even during the late War. The Legislatures of all the New-England States except Vermont, have recently been in Session, without receiving a single petition for the suspension of Specie payments, or indeed any particular complaints, of distress. But as commercial and navigating, it will reach them by reflection, from the South and West— The profits of Commerce and of shipping must fall after the price of the exports has been so much reduced as necessarily to reduce in return the quantity of importations— The distress in that quarter will therefore come later; but it will come,
and as in the meanwhile, it will be continually growing heavier, in the others, the day of desperate expedients may finally reach them all, and what I apprehend is that paper money with all its numberless evils will be the consequence— Time and Chance, that is a superintending Providence, may work out a remedy. Would that it were within the means of my intelligence to compass it! Crawford said he had a Letter from General Smith of Baltimore, stating that he was irretrievably ruined, and quite unexpectedly to himself; for, that he had implicitly relied upon his partner Buchanan, who had managed all the Affairs of the house, and who always represented them to him as prosperous. At the Office, I was comparing with Mr Brent the manuscript copy of the Secret Journal of the old Congress— Forbes came and spent an hour with me this Evening.

25. IV:30. In re-examining the Accounts of agency of my brother during my absence in Europe, it occurred to me as necessary to enter them in some form, upon my own Books, and although they include the management of all my property in this Country for eight years, I found they could be reduced to a small number of items, the whole amount of the receipts and payments upon which could be entered as Dr and Cr. on two pages of my Waste-Book and Journal; reserving the transactions relating to the purchase of United States Bank Shares for a separate account on another page. I had already made a summary, from the Accounts last year, exhibiting on a page the receipts and payments of each year, and I was engaged all this morning in preparing the compression of the whole. I resumed the work again in the Evening, without approaching towards a conclusion— At home I could attend to nothing else and the arrears of my Diary still run on. At the Office, Mr Worthington, late Agent at Buenos-Ayres, and in Chili, came to ask for a settlement of his Accounts— But as he claims allowances which the President only can make, the Settlement must await his return. I told Worthington however that he might in the meantime receive a part of his claims on Account.

26. IV:30.Mr Greuhm the Prussian Minister, called to take leave. He is going with the Viscount de Quabeck, upon an excursion of a Month to Pittsburg and other parts of the Western Country. My pursuit upon my brothers Accounts tied me down till it was one O’Clock, instead of eleven, when I called upon Mr King to sit for my Portrait. He was then expecting Mr De Neuville, and we agreed to postpone my sitting until next Tuesday— At the Office, I continued with Mr Brent the examination of the Secret Journals— Just after dinner, Mr Hersant came with an invitation from Mr Hyde de Neuville, that I would go, and spend the Evening with a small party there—I went, and found among others the Abbe Correa, who has returned for a few days from Philadelphia. Mr Todd, Mrs Madison’s son was also there and beat me at Chess. There was music—the Miss Middleton’s sung with the Piano, and Miss Van Ness with the Harp—very well— A warm day— Fahrenheit at 80. It was Midnight when I came home.

27. VI: The Viscount de Quabeck called and took leave, previous to his intended excursion with Mr Greuhm. The heat of the weather kept me confined to the house till the Evening. I made out the accounts of my brothers agency for me, from 1809–to 1817. and of his purchase for me, of U.S. Bank Shares, and entered them upon my Waste-Book, and Journal— The examination into which I have gone for this purpose has led me to an apprehension that in making the Settlement with my brother of 8. September 1817. there was a mistake made to his disadvantage of between two and four hundred dollars— I therefore wrote him a Letter giving him this information, and renewing the request of a joint revision by us together of these accounts for the purpose of rectifying that error if it has been committed— The investigation of these accounts and of my own, has also discovered to me many errors, in the forms of entry upon my Books— My Waste-Book and Book of Family Expences contain a full and most exact Statement of my property, and of all my transactions relating to it from the first of January 1802— But at that time I began the attempt which I have ever since continued of keeping my Books in the regular form of Merchants Accounts, by double entry according to what is called the Italian Method. But never having been taught this system, I merely studied it for a short time in Mair’s Book-keeping, and practiced it without being aware of its difficulties— These I have found numerous, and arising from various sources.— Some from making the entries at a wrong time— Some from making them to
a wrong Account, or to the wrong side of an account, a mistake which would seem scarcely possible at the first view, but of which with the system of fictitious accounts, there is continual danger— The accounts of cash of profit and loss, of Interest—those of Family Expences, Library, Household Furniture, are constantly running into one another. In taking or giving Notes or Bonds, I sometimes debit or credit the person, and sometimes Bills receivable or payable; and what is much worse, I have sometimes debited Bills Receivable for a Note, and when the payment was made, perhaps years afterwards, have forgotten the original entry, and credited the person who gave the Note—the result of which presents the person as my Creditor on my own Books, and no debt to balance it— Differences of Exchange, advances or discounts upon nominal sums, complications of Accounts with the same person in different capacities, all lead to erroneous entries, and sometimes I have forgotten to make any entry, when one should have been made. Last of all, as I have made a great number of entries in my Book of Household or Family Expences, which are also entered to separate Accounts in the Journal and Ledger; and as Cash is made the general Creditor to Family-Expences, and at the same time the special Creditor to the separate charge on the Journal, it receives a double credit to the same debt. My Cash Account accordingly very soon got out of order, and although I have taken great and repeated pains with it, has never been restored to its balance— And as the correctness of all Books thus kept, depends upon that of the Cash Account, my Books have got into a confusion as yet inextricable to myself— They present a very inaccurate picture of my Estate and of my transactions relating to it— This remark applies however only to the technical part, the Journal and Ledger Entries, in Mercantile form— The Waste-Book and the Book of Family-Expences contain an Account as exact and minute of all my pecuniary transactions and concerns as perhaps was ever kept by any man. I could perhaps now commence Books according to the mode of Merchants Accounts and keep them in regular order; where I have stumbled, I should now know that there is a stone. And yet without vigilant and uninterrupted attention, they would get into the same disorder— This notice may serve to explain that in which it is probable my Mercantile Journal and Ledger may hereafter be found by my legal Representatives. This Evening I took an hour’s walk, and called on Mrs W. S. Smith. Found there Mary Hellen, who came home with me— Fahrenheit at 88.

28. V:30. Engaged all this Morning still upon my Account-Books. Captain O’Brien came to the Office, and took his papers, to exhibit them to the fifth Auditor Mr Pleasonton— The heat of the day was intolerable. Fahrenheit, at 90. I could only compare with Mr Brent the secret Journals of the Old Congress. There was in the Evening a very heavy, thunder-gust and shower. Just before it came on Mr E. B. Caldwell, called at my house with a Mr Fiske, who with a Mr Parsons, is going as a religious Missionary to Judea, and who came to enquire if I could give them Passports or other facilities for proceeding upon their Mission. They enquired if there was any Public Officer of the United States in any of the Ottoman dominions— There are only the Consuls at the Barbary Powers. Their project is to go first to England, and there obtain Letters of Recommendation and perhaps protection. I offered Passports and Letters to Mr Rush, and Mr Gallatin. Mr Fiske is to consult the Committee of the Missionary Society; and will then call upon me again.

29. VI:Mr Wrifford, a teacher of writing, upon a system peculiar to himself came to ask my name to a subscription paper, for lessons to be given by him at Mr M’Phail’s School. I subscribed for Mary Hellen who is attending at the School. I sat, between two and three hours to King the Painter. He is one of the best Portrait Painters, in this Country; little inferior to Stewart— He is also an ingenious, thinking man, with a faculty of conversing upon almost every topic. He lead me this day into a long colloquy upon religion, and morals; theology and infidelity— He has no faith in Christianity but professes to be a deist— But his examination of the subject has been very scanty— At the Office, Matthew Maury, a Son of the Consul at Liverpool, came and offered
to take any Letters of despatches for England. He goes to embark at New-York in one of the Liverpool Packets, the 10th. of next Month— Captain O’Brien called again— There was a heavy thunder-shower again this Evening.

30. IV:30. My Diary had again imperceptibly run a full week in arrears; because I have suffered other objects to absorb all my time; I resumed it seriously this Morning, and it engaged me till the time of attendance at the Office— Mr George Hay came to enquire for the 61st. Number of the Edinburgh-Review, and for the Exposition of the Causes of the late War with Great-Britain, which was written by the late Mr Dallas. I had not received the Review, and referred him to the 8th. Volume of Niles’s Register, for the Exposition. Mr Antrobus the British Charge d’Affaires, came to the Office with a Letter from Coll. Barclay, the British Commissioner under the fifth Article of the Treaty of Ghent, written at New-York the 25th. instt. and mentioning that the proceedings of the Commission were arrested, by the non-appearance of an American Astronomer, in the place of Mr Hassler, to make the Astronomical observations jointly with the British Astronomer Dr Tiack’s. I had written on the 27th. of May to Mr Ellicott at West-Point requesting him to take Hassler’s place, and to Major Thayer, requesting him to give Ellicott leave of absence for the purpose, and enclosed the Letters to the Commissioner Van Ness— Having received no reply from either of them, I am apprehensive that Van Ness has not received my Letter— I directed duplicates to be immediately forwarded to him. Triplicates of the Letters to Thayer and Ellicott to be addressed directly to them at West-Point, and that the Post-master at New-York should be immediately written to, and enquired of, about the Letter to Van Ness— There was again this Evening, some of the heaviest thunder I ever heard; but almost without wind, and with a very light Shower.

Day. The range of my rising hour is from four to six— The average five, which if I could observe it the year round, would be approaching as near to regularity as the imperfection of my nature will admit. At the times when the tides in the river serve, I bathe in the Potowmac near the Bridge. The walk to the spot is a mile and a half, and with half an hour in bathing, it takes from an hour and a half to two hours of the Mornings on which I take this exercise— I find it as always heretofore, conducive to health, cleanliness and comfort— The reading and assortment of Newspapers; the Diary of the preceding day; other miscellaneous occasional writing, or reading; the Convention-Journals and my Account Books, have occupied the hours till nine, and with the interval of half an hour for breakfast till twelve or one, when I repair to my Office— There the current business employs me till past five, when I return home, and dine at six— After dinner, I read the newspapers till dark, and when the weather is not too warm, an hour or two by candle-light. Sometimes I walk or ride out in the Evening— Sometimes spend it abroad and sometimes with visitors at home— The hour of retiring to bed is from nine to eleven, which seldom is postponed till so late as Midnight. The Month has been unusually warm.
